name: Forces
subject: Science
description: An introduction to forces, including types of forces, simple machines, balanced and unbalanced forces, and gravity.

subtopics.name: Understanding Forces
subtopics.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental concept of what a force is, how forces affect objects, and how we represent and measure forces. You will learn that forces are pushes or pulls that always involve an interaction between two objects.
subtopics.why: Understanding forces is essential because forces explain why objects move, stop, speed up, slow down, or change shape. Every physical interaction you experience involves forces, from opening a door to catching a ball.

items.title: I can define a force as a push or a pull that involves an interaction between two objects
items.what: A force is not something an object contains. It always involves one object exerting a push or pull on another object.
items.why: This definition helps you identify forces in any situation by looking for the two objects involved in the interaction.
items.example: When you kick a football, your foot (object 1) exerts a push force on the ball (object 2). The force is the interaction between your foot and the ball.

toLevel4.question: When you kick a football, how many objects are involved in the force?
toLevel4.correct: Two objects: your foot and the ball
toLevel4.correctExplanation: A force always involves an interaction between two objects - in this case, your foot pushing against the ball.

distractors.explanation: A force requires two objects interacting. The ball alone cannot experience a force without something else acting on it.

distractors.answer: Three objects: foot, leg, and ball
distractors.explanation: While your leg is connected to your foot, the force interaction is specifically between your foot (the part making contact) and the ball.

distractors.answer: No objects - force is just energy
distractors.explanation: Forces are not energy. A force is specifically a push or pull between two objects that are interacting.

toLevel4.question: Which statement best describes what a force is?
toLevel4.correct: An interaction between two objects involving a push or pull
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Forces always involve two objects and are either pushes or pulls - this is the fundamental definition.

distractors.explanation: Force is not stored energy. Force is an interaction that happens between objects, not something contained within them.

distractors.answer: The speed at which something moves
distractors.explanation: Speed is how fast something moves. Force is what causes changes in motion, but they are different concepts.
Weight is one specific type of force (gravitational), but force as a concept is broader - any push or pull between two objects.

toLevel5.question: A magnet attracts a paperclip from a distance without touching it. Which statement correctly identifies the two objects involved in this force interaction?
toLevel5.correct: The magnet and the paperclip are the two interacting objects
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Even though they're not touching, the magnetic force is still an interaction between two objects: the magnet and the paperclip.

distractors.answer: Only the magnet is involved since it creates the force
distractors.explanation: Forces always require two objects. The magnet doesn't 'own' the force - it's an interaction between the magnet AND the paperclip.

distractors.answer: The magnet, the air, and the paperclip are all involved
distractors.explanation: The air is not part of the magnetic force interaction. Magnetic forces act directly between magnetic objects regardless of air.

distractors.answer: There is no force since they aren't touching
distractors.explanation: Non-contact forces like magnetism can act at a distance. The two objects (magnet and paperclip) are still interacting even without touching.

toLevel5.question: If someone says 'the ball has a lot of force', why is this statement scientifically incorrect?
toLevel5.correct: Force is not something an object contains - it only exists as an interaction between two objects
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Objects don't 'have' or 'contain' force. Force only exists when two objects interact through a push or pull.

distractors.answer: Balls are too small to have force
distractors.explanation: Size doesn't determine whether something can be involved in a force. The issue is that NO object 'contains' force - force is always an interaction.

distractors.answer: Only living things can have force
distractors.explanation: Neither living nor non-living things 'have' force. Force exists only as an interaction between objects, not as something stored inside them.
The statement incorrectly implies force is a property objects possess. Force is always an interaction between two objects, not something contained within one object.

items.title: I can classify a force as either a push or a pull
items.what: Every force can be categorised as either pushing (moving objects away) or pulling (drawing objects closer).
items.why: Being able to identify the type of force helps you predict how an object will respond to that force.
items.example: Dragging a sled over snow is a pull. Pressing a button on a keyboard is a push.

items.title: I can identify the six effects that forces can have on objects
items.what: Forces can: start an object moving, stop an object moving, speed up a moving object, slow down a moving object, change the direction of a moving object, or change the shape of an object.
items.why: Recognising these effects allows you to work backwards from what you observe to identify what forces must be acting.
items.example: When a tennis player hits a ball with a racquet, the force changes the direction the ball is moving. When you knead dough, the force changes its shape.

items.title: I can use force arrows to represent the strength and direction of forces
items.what: In diagrams, arrows represent forces. The length of the arrow shows the strength of the force (longer = stronger), and the direction of the arrow shows which way the force acts.
items.why: Force diagrams allow you to visualise and compare multiple forces acting on an object, which helps predict how the object will move.
items.example: A diagram of a book on a table shows a short arrow pointing down (gravity) and an equally short arrow pointing up (the table pushing back). Equal arrow lengths show balanced forces.

items.title: I can state that forces are measured in newtons (N)
items.what: The newton is the unit of force, named after Isaac Newton. The symbol is a capital N.
items.why: Using standard units allows scientists to communicate and compare force measurements precisely.
items.example: The force of gravity on an apple is about 1 N. A 1-litre carton of milk pushes down on your hand with about 10 N.

items.title: I can use a spring balance to measure forces
items.what: A spring balance measures force by showing how much a spring stretches when a force is applied to it.
items.why: Spring balances are practical tools for measuring forces in experiments, allowing you to collect quantitative data.
items.example: To measure the force needed to drag a jug across a desk, attach the spring balance to the jug and pull steadily while reading the scale at the moment the jug starts moving.

subtopics.name: Types of Forces
subtopics.what: This subtopic covers the different types of forces you encounter in everyday life, including applied force, gravity, tension, magnetism, friction, air resistance, water resistance, and elastic force. You will also learn to classify these as contact or non-contact forces.
subtopics.why: Different types of forces have different causes and behave differently. Identifying the type of force helps you understand and predict how objects will interact in various situations.

items.title: I can identify an applied force as a push or pull exerted by a person, animal, or machine
items.what: An applied force is any force that is deliberately exerted on an object by something else.
items.why: Applied forces are the most common forces we control in everyday life, from pushing a shopping trolley to pulling open a drawer.
items.example: When a person pushes a couch across the floor, they are exerting an applied force on the couch.

items.title: I can describe gravity as a force of attraction between all objects with mass
items.what: Gravity pulls objects toward each other. The more massive the objects, the stronger the gravitational attraction.
items.why: Gravity keeps us on Earth, causes objects to fall, and holds planets in orbit around the Sun.
items.example: When you drop a ball, gravity pulls it toward the Earth. The Earth is also pulled slightly toward the ball, but the Earth is so massive that this movement is undetectable.

items.title: I can define tension as an inward pulling force in a stretched object
items.what: Tension occurs in ropes, cables, and strings when they are pulled tight. The force acts along the length of the object.
items.why: Tension forces are important in structures like bridges and in everyday objects like bags with straps.
items.example: When you carry a bag by its strap, the strap experiences tension. The tension force pulls inward along the strap, supporting the weight of the bag.

items.title: I can explain that magnetism is a force of attraction or repulsion between certain materials
items.what: Magnetic forces act between materials containing iron, cobalt, or nickel. Unlike gravity, magnetism can either attract or repel.
items.why: Magnetism is used in many technologies, from fridge magnets to electric motors and computer hard drives.
items.example: Magnetic letters stick to a fridge door because the magnetic force attracts them to the metal surface of the fridge.

items.title: I can describe friction as a force that resists the motion of one object relative to another
items.what: Friction occurs when surfaces rub against each other. It acts in the opposite direction to the motion or attempted motion.
items.why: Friction allows us to walk without slipping and helps cars grip the road. It also causes wear on moving parts and generates heat.
items.example: When a coffee cup slides across a table, friction between the cup and table acts in the opposite direction to the cup's motion, causing it to slow down and stop.

items.title: I can identify air resistance and water resistance as types of friction
items.what: Air resistance slows objects moving through air. Water resistance slows objects moving through water. Both act opposite to the direction of motion.
items.why: These forces affect the speed of vehicles, falling objects, and swimmers, and must be considered in design and performance.
items.example: A parachute works by increasing air resistance. The large surface area of the parachute creates a strong upward air resistance force that slows the skydiver's fall.

items.title: I can explain that elastic force causes stretched or compressed objects to return to their original shape
items.what: When you stretch or squash an elastic object, it exerts a force trying to return to its original shape.
items.why: Elastic forces are used in springs, rubber bands, and bouncy balls, and explain why these objects behave the way they do.
items.example: When a soft ball hits the ground and bounces, the ball compresses on impact. The elastic force pushes the ball back up as it returns to its original shape.

items.title: I can classify forces as either contact or non-contact forces
items.what: Contact forces require objects to be touching (friction, applied force, tension, elastic force, air resistance, water resistance). Non-contact forces can act at a distance without touching (gravity, magnetism).
items.why: This classification helps identify what forces might be acting on an object by checking what it's touching and what non-contact forces might apply.
items.example: A ball flying through the air experiences gravity (non-contact, always present) and air resistance (contact, because the ball touches the air molecules).

subtopics.name: Simple Machines
subtopics.what: This subtopic covers how simple machines like ramps, levers, and pulleys change the magnitude or direction of forces. You will learn about effort force, the parts of a lever, and how to calculate the efficiency of simple machines.
subtopics.why: Simple machines have been used throughout history to accomplish tasks that would otherwise be impossible, from building pyramids to modern construction. Understanding them helps you see how engineering makes work easier.

items.title: I can explain that a simple machine changes the magnitude or direction of a force
items.what: Simple machines are devices with few or no moving parts that make work easier by changing how forces are applied.
items.why: Simple machines allow us to lift heavy objects, move things more easily, or apply forces in more convenient directions.
items.example: A ramp allows you to move a heavy box to a higher level by pushing it along a slope instead of lifting it straight up. You use less force, but over a longer distance.

items.title: I can identify the six types of simple machines
items.what: The six simple machines are: lever, inclined plane (ramp), wedge, pulley, screw, and wheel and axle.
items.why: Recognising these categories helps you identify how different tools and devices work to make tasks easier.
items.example: A hammer removing a nail uses lever action. A corkscrew combines a screw and a lever. A skateboard ramp is an inclined plane.

items.title: I can define effort force as the force used to move an object
items.what: The effort force is the force you apply to a simple machine to move a load. Simple machines can reduce the effort force needed.
items.why: Understanding effort force helps you predict how much force you need to apply when using different machines.
items.example: When dragging a bag of rice up a ramp, the effort force is the force you apply by pulling. A gentler ramp requires less effort force than a steep one.

items.title: I can describe how the angle of inclination of a ramp affects the effort force required
items.what: A smaller angle of inclination (gentler slope) requires less effort force but a longer distance. A larger angle requires more effort force over a shorter distance.
items.why: This trade-off between force and distance is fundamental to how ramps work and must be considered in practical applications.
items.example: The ancient Egyptians used long, gently sloped ramps to move heavy stone blocks up the pyramids. The gentle slope reduced the effort force needed, even though the total distance was much longer.

items.title: I can identify the three parts of a lever: fulcrum, effort arm, and resistance arm
items.what: The fulcrum is the pivot point. The effort arm is where force is applied. The resistance arm is connected to the object being moved.
items.why: Knowing these parts allows you to understand how different lever designs change the force or speed of movement.
items.example: On a see-saw, the fulcrum is the central pivot. Your legs push down on one effort arm, and your friend on the other side is the resistance.

items.title: I can distinguish between force multipliers and speed multipliers
items.what: Force multipliers have a longer effort arm than resistance arm, reducing the effort needed. Speed multipliers have a longer resistance arm, increasing the speed of the output.
items.why: Different tasks require different lever designs. Lifting heavy loads needs force multiplication; throwing far needs speed multiplication.
items.example: A wheelbarrow is a force multiplier‚Äîthe long handles let you lift heavy loads with less effort. A cricket bat is a speed multiplier‚Äîthe long bat makes the ball travel faster than your hands move.

items.title: I can explain how pulleys change the force needed to lift an object
items.what: A single pulley changes the direction of a force. Multiple pulleys can reduce the effort force needed to lift a load.
items.why: Pulleys are used in construction, sailing, and many other applications where heavy loads need to be lifted or moved.
items.example: With a single pulley, you pull down to lift something up‚Äîsame force, different direction. With two pulleys, you might need only half the effort force to lift the same load.

items.title: I can calculate the efficiency of a simple machine using the formula: efficiency = (force without machine √∑ force with machine) √ó 100
items.what: Efficiency tells you how much easier a simple machine makes a task, expressed as a percentage.
items.why: Comparing efficiency helps you choose the best tool for a job and understand the trade-offs involved.
items.example: If lifting a bag of rice requires 2.1 N without a machine and 1.5 N with a wheel and axle, the efficiency is (2.1 √∑ 1.5) √ó 100 = 140%. The higher the percentage, the more the machine helps.

subtopics.name: Balanced and Unbalanced Forces
subtopics.what: This subtopic covers how multiple forces acting on an object combine to produce balanced or unbalanced situations, and how to calculate the net force. You will learn to predict whether an object will change its motion based on the forces acting on it.
subtopics.why: Understanding balanced and unbalanced forces explains why some objects stay still, others move at constant speed, and others speed up, slow down, or change direction. This is fundamental to predicting motion.

items.title: I can explain that balanced forces are equal in size and opposite in direction
items.what: When forces on an object are balanced, they cancel each other out and have no effect on the object's motion.
items.why: Recognising balanced forces explains why objects at rest stay at rest and why moving objects can continue at constant speed.
items.example: A book on a table has gravity pulling it down and the table pushing it up. These forces are equal and opposite, so the book stays still.

items.title: I can identify that balanced forces can act on both stationary and moving objects
items.what: An object with balanced forces will maintain its current state‚Äîif stationary, it stays still; if moving, it continues at the same speed and direction.
items.why: This corrects the common misconception that balanced forces only apply to objects that are not moving.
items.example: A skydiver at terminal velocity has balanced forces‚Äîgravity pulling down equals air resistance pushing up. Even though the forces are balanced, the skydiver continues falling at a constant speed.

items.title: I can explain that unbalanced forces cause a change in an object's motion
items.what: When forces are unbalanced, the object will speed up, slow down, start moving, stop moving, or change direction.
items.why: Unbalanced forces are responsible for all changes in motion, which is essential for understanding how objects accelerate or decelerate.
items.example: When a car brakes, friction from the brakes creates an unbalanced force that slows the car down. The backward friction force is greater than any forward force, so the car decelerates.

items.title: I can define net force as the overall force acting on an object
items.what: Net force is the result of combining all forces acting on an object. It tells you the overall effect of those forces.
items.why: Calculating net force allows you to predict how an object will move without having to consider each individual force separately.
items.example: If three people push a trolley‚Äîtwo pushing left with 100 N each and one pushing right with 50 N‚Äîthe net force is 200 N - 50 N = 150 N to the left.

items.title: I can calculate net force when forces act in opposite directions by subtracting the smaller from the larger
items.what: When forces act in opposite directions, they partially cancel. Subtract the smaller force from the larger to find the net force, which acts in the direction of the larger force.
items.why: This calculation is used constantly in physics to determine how objects will move when multiple opposing forces act on them.
items.example: A parachutist experiences 1500 N of gravity downward and 800 N of air resistance upward. Net force = 1500 N - 800 N = 700 N downward. The parachutist accelerates downward.

items.title: I can calculate net force when forces act in the same direction by adding them
items.what: When forces act in the same direction, they combine to produce a larger net force in that direction.
items.why: This explains why two people pushing together can move something that neither could move alone.
items.example: Two cyclists on a tandem bike push with 200 N and 150 N in the same direction. Net force = 200 N + 150 N = 350 N forward.

items.title: I can determine that the net force is zero when forces are balanced
items.what: When all forces cancel out exactly, the net force is 0 N, and there is no change in the object's motion.
items.why: A net force of zero is the condition for equilibrium, where objects either remain stationary or continue moving at constant velocity.
items.example: In a tug-of-war where neither team is moving, the pulling forces are equal and opposite. Net force = 0 N, so the rope stays in place.

subtopics.name: Gravity and Weight
subtopics.what: This subtopic covers gravitational fields, gravitational field strength, and the important distinction between mass and weight. You will learn to calculate weight using the formula W = m √ó g and understand why astronauts appear weightless.
subtopics.why: Gravity affects everything on Earth and beyond. Understanding gravitational fields and the difference between mass and weight is essential for understanding space travel, planetary motion, and everyday phenomena like falling objects.

items.title: I can explain that a gravitational field is the region around an object where another object experiences gravitational force
items.what: Every object with mass has a gravitational field surrounding it. Any other object within that field will experience a gravitational pull toward the first object.
items.why: The concept of fields helps explain how gravity can act at a distance without objects touching.
items.example: The Earth has a gravitational field extending far into space. The Moon is within Earth's gravitational field, which is why it orbits Earth rather than drifting away.

items.title: I can describe how gravitational field strength decreases with distance from an object
items.what: The further you are from an object, the weaker its gravitational pull on you. Gravitational field strength is measured in newtons per kilogram (N/kg).
items.why: This explains why astronauts in orbit experience weaker gravity than people on Earth's surface, and why distant planets have little gravitational effect on us.
items.example: Earth's gravitational field strength is 9.8 N/kg at the surface but only about 8.8 N/kg at the height of the International Space Station (370 km up).

items.title: I can distinguish between mass and weight
items.what: Mass is the amount of matter in an object, measured in kilograms (kg). Weight is the gravitational force on an object, measured in newtons (N). Mass stays constant; weight changes depending on gravitational field strength.
items.why: Confusing mass and weight is a common error. Understanding the difference is essential for solving problems involving gravity and for understanding space travel.
items.example: A 50 kg person has the same mass on Earth and the Moon. But their weight on Earth is about 490 N, while on the Moon (weaker gravity) it is only about 81 N.

items.title: I can calculate weight using the formula W = m √ó g
items.what: Weight equals mass multiplied by gravitational field strength. W is weight in newtons, m is mass in kilograms, and g is gravitational field strength in N/kg.
items.why: This formula allows you to calculate the gravitational force on any object at any location if you know its mass and the local gravitational field strength.
items.example: Calculate the weight of a 2 kg brick on Venus (g = 8.8 N/kg): W = m √ó g = 2 kg √ó 8.8 N/kg = 17.6 N

items.title: I can explain why astronauts on the International Space Station appear weightless
items.what: Astronauts appear weightless because they and the space station are both falling toward Earth at the same rate while moving sideways fast enough to keep missing it (orbiting). They still have weight‚Äîgravity still acts on them.
items.why: This corrects the misconception that there is no gravity in space. Astronauts are not truly weightless; they are in continuous free fall.
items.example: An 80 kg astronaut on the ISS still has a weight of about 704 N (using g = 8.8 N/kg at that altitude). They float because the station falls with them, not because gravity has disappeared.
